info.game_comments:
2000 Tournament of Champions quarterfinal game 3.
From the Atlanta Civic Center.

(1, 1).clue: The June 1983 Challenger flight had the first 5-person crew, including this first U.S. woman in space

(2, 1).clue: In this 1971 hit, Don McLean wrote that "Something touched me deep inside the day the music died"

(3, 1).clue: 3-letter abbreviation for a type of line that keeps you constantly connected at high speed

(4, 1).clue: These come in a variety of sizes from small to supercolossal & are often stuffed with pimientos

(5, 1).clue: Aye, matey, Anne Bonny & Mary Read lived the high life on the high seas as this type of criminal

(6, 1).clue: In the 2-letter abbreviation of the Bluegrass State

(1, 2).clue: After going to the moon, Pete Conrad & Alan Bean's next trips were to this U.S. space station

(2, 2).clue: In 1978 the Bee Gees spent a total of 13 weeks at No. 1 & this youngest brother took the top spot for 9 weeks

(3, 2).clue: Zone names include com, gov, net & this one found after www.stanford & www.hofstra

(4, 2).clue: This fermented cabbage dish is a popular ingredient in a Reuben sandwich

(5, 2).clue: "The Last Madam" is a recent book about Norma Wallace, who ran a famous brothel in this city's French Quarter

(6, 2).clue: In the abbreviation of the military duty in which you assist the cook

(1, 3).clue: James Lovell went on 2 Apollo missions & 2 of these missions that had 2-man crews

(2, 3).clue: "Roll Over Beethoven and tell" this Russian composer "the news"

(3, 3).clue: PGP, a popular e-mail encryption program, stands for "Pretty Good" this

(4, 3).clue: This tasty veal dish derives its name from the German for "Viennese cutlet"

(5, 3).clue: A 1944 Broadway musical fictionalized the life of this 19th C. feminist known for her scandalous pants

(6, 3).clue: On highway distance signs in Europe

(1, 4).clue: With Deke Slayton grounded with a heart condition, this man got to be the second U.S. man in space

(2, 4).clue: Hoyt Axton wrote 2 of this group's Top 5 hits:  "Joy To The World" & "Never Been To Spain"

(3, 4).clue: Area 51 & Heartland are "neighborhoods" in this web page hosting service from Yahoo!

(4, 4).clue: From French for "to strike" or "chill", it's a tall, cool coffee drink blended with sugar & ice

(5, 4).clue: Some say this "maternal" outlaw arranged the murder of her lover, Arthur Dunlop

(6, 4).clue: In the common name of the airline whose mileage program is called "Flying Dutchman"

(1, 5).clue: Astronaut Michael Foale was left in the dark in June 1997 after a supply ship punctured this craft's Spektr module

(2, 5).clue: This Stevie Wonder hit is subtitled "Everything's Alright"

(3, 5).clue: This network that encompasses thousands of news groups was created in 1979 by 2 Duke University grad students

(4, 5).clue: How sweet it is!  This onion is Georgia's state vegetable

(5, 5).clue: Born Martha, this Wild West gal, Wild Bill Hickok's pal, sometimes toiled as a lady of the evening

(6, 5).clue: In the symbol of the colorless, odorless gas whose atomic number is 36

(1, 1).clue: This star had close encounters in "Men In Black" & "Independence Day"

(2, 1).clue: These 2 countries form the Scandinavian Peninsula

(3, 1).clue: This west coast Major League Baseball team is the only one with both its city name & team name in a foreign language

(4, 1).clue: One of these seen in 1769 had a tail estimated to be about 40 million miles long

(5, 1).clue: This Peter Shaffer tragedy focuses on the life of a great composer, as seen by his rival in the Austrian court

(6, 1).clue: As Jean-Paul Sartre rejected this award in 1964, the big cash prize was returned to its fund

(1, 2).clue: Fictional TV series on which Jason Nesmith played Commander Taggart (& Tim Allen played them both)

(2, 2).clue: Jabal Katrinah, Egypt's highest point, rises 8,651 feet in the southern part of this peninsula

(3, 2).clue: This Norse word for a fierce warrior is now associated with "going" nuts

(4, 2).clue: An island first seen in 1767 by a sailor with this last name was colonized in 1790 by mutineers

(5, 2).clue: Stephen Flaherty, not Scott Joplin, wrote the music for this show that's based on a novel by E.L. Doctorow

(6, 2).clue: He was "Alabama Joe" back in 1964 but failed to lead 'Bama to an Orange Bowl win

(1, 3).clue: Douglas Rain, who performed this role in "2001:  A Space Odyssey", never visited the set

(2, 3).clue: Bertram Thomas was the first European to cross the Rub Al-Khali, the "Empty Quarter" of this peninsula

(3, 3).clue: Selections by this French classical composer include "Tortoises", "Aquarium" & "The Elephant"

(4, 3).clue: In the 1790s the French made Toussaint L'Ouverture general-in-chief of this colony

(5, 3).clue: Olga, Masha & Irina Prozorov are the title characters in this play

(6, 3).clue: This city announced in January 1964 that it would build not 1, but 2 tallest buildings in the world

(1, 4).clue: In 1998 this "Party Of Five" member was one of a party of seven "Lost In Space"

(2, 4).clue: This continent's northernmost tip lies on land once called Palmer Peninsula by the U.S. & Graham Land by the British

(3, 4).clue: This publishing company founded in 1939 made Gertrude the Kangaroo its mascot

(4, 4).clue: France's political & social system before the revolution was known as the "Ancien" this

(5, 4).clue: He wrote, "Was this the face that launched a thousand ships, and burnt the topless towers of Ilium?"

(6, 4).clue: This former prime minister was cremated on a sandalwood pyre beside the Jumna River May 28, 1964

(1, 5).clue: In "The Phantom Menace" she played Padme Naberrie

(2, 5).clue: This peninsula on Luzon Island in the Philippines fell to the Japanese on April 9, 1942

(3, 5).clue: Translated as "Land of the Kings", this state is home to India's nuclear test sites & the world's largest camel fair

(4, 5).clue: In 1757 this man led the East India Company's forces to victory in the Battle of Plassey

(5, 5).clue: Christopher Isherwood & Sally Bowles are characters in this 1951 play on which a 1966 musical was partly based
(5, 5).correct response: I Am A Camera (The musical was "Cabaret")

(6, 5).clue: Princess Irene of Orange-Nassau lost her claim to this country's throne because she married a Spanish Catholic

(0, 0).clue: An edition of this 1934 book had on its cover a crab & "Not to be imported into Great Britain or U.S.A."
